name: Wonderful Complexity Trucker Hat (LIMITED EDITION)
description:
We're only making 25 (TWENTY-FIVE) of these Wonderful Complexity trucker hats. Each will come signed by Omri on the under-side of the bill. Plus, a free WC sticker with each hat.

Get yours.

name: Omri 'Vapors Volume II' (CD)
description:
Track Listing:
  1. Selah
  2. Ink On It (feat. Katie Eckeberger of My Anchor Holds and Barabbas Da Rebel)
  3. Word Watch
  4. True Brutality
  5. These Lessons (feat. Israel Capo)
  6. Up (feat. JG, God’s Servant, and Pilgrim)
CD's include instrumental versions of all tracks.

name: 'Slave Trade' EP
description: About Slave Trade No whips. No chains. No plantations. Yet everyone is still a slave. Slavery usually causes thoughts of savage and inhumane treatment, but regardless of what comes to mind, the truth of the matter is, we’re all slaves. And like all slaves, we are bound to the will of our master. All men obey the one that they are enslaved to - either Jesus and righteousness or sin and Satan. It is this truth that J. Miles seeks to communicate with his debut EP, Slave Trade. Just as slaves experienced times of intense joy, hope, the burden of daily toil, and anguish because of life’s hardships, Slave Trade engages listeners in a range of experiences musically. From the personal heart-felt tone of Love Letters, featuring the melodic voice of Leah Smith, to the energetic beat and catchy hook on Kill It For His Glory, as well as the lyrical complexity of Identical Strangers, Slave Trade is sure to engage listeners of all types. The heart behind the truths communicated on Slave Trade initially came out of a sermon series on Romans 6. It was through these teachings that J. Miles was challenged and convicted to allow the truth about his identity as Jesus’ slave to be his strongest motivation to live a life of obedience. J. Miles has grown to love and enjoy freedom from sin and slavery to Jesus, and it is his hope that Slave Trade will encourage others, and also beg the question, “Who’s Your Master?” Tracklisting: 1. Slave Trade 2. Adopted (feat. Barabbas Da Rebel & J. Paul) 3. Identical Strangers 4. Keep Your Heart (feat. Omri) 5. Love Letters (feat. Leah Smith) 6. Kill It For His Glory (feat JG) 7. Why?

name: 'Slave Trade' EP + Slave t-shirt
description: This special package includes 1 'Slave' t-shirt (blue) About Slave Trade No whips. No chains. No plantations. Yet everyone is still a slave. Slavery usually causes thoughts of savage and inhumane treatment, but regardless of what comes to mind, the truth of the matter is, we’re all slaves. And like all slaves, we are bound to the will of our master. All men obey the one that they are enslaved to - either Jesus and righteousness or sin and Satan. It is this truth that J. Miles seeks to communicate with his debut EP, Slave Trade. From the personal heart-felt tone of Love Letters, featuring the melodic voice of Leah Smith, to the energetic beat and catchy hook on Kill It For His Glory, as well as the lyrical complexity of Identical Strangers, Slave Trade is sure to engage listeners of all types. Miles was challenged and convicted to allow the truth about his identity as Jesus’ slave to be his strongest motivation to live a life of obedience. J. Miles has grown to love and enjoy freedom from sin and slavery to Jesus, and it is his hope that Slave Trade will encourage others, and also beg the question, “Who’s Your Master?” Tracklisting: 1. Slave Trade 2. Adopted (feat. Barabbas Da Rebel & J. Paul) 3. Identical Strangers 4. Keep Your Heart (feat. Omri) 5. Love Letters (feat. Leah Smith) 6. Kill It For His Glory (feat JG) 7. Why? DOULOS δοῦλος - a Greek word identifying one who is subservient to another; a slave The writers of Scripture joyfully proclaimed their enslavement to the Lord Jesus who had freed them from sin through his own crucifixion (Romans 6). You too can boldly declare your enslavement to Christ with this exclusive Slave Trade tee.

name: White iSix:5 Seraph T-shirt
description:
As the iSix:5 name comes from Isaiah 6:5, the logo depicts the humble position of the seraphim within that same chapter of Scripture.

"Above him stood the seraphim. Each had six wings: with two he covered his face, and with two he covered his feet, and with two he flew."

- Isaiah 6:2
